title: Chef forgives drunken ‘mac and cheese’ student
text:
YouTube Bill McKay pinned Luke Gatti to the ground after the intoxicated teen shoved the Union Street Market manager. The Union Street Market employee who helped restrain a drunken University of Connecticut student who aggressively demanded a plate of mac and cheese has pardoned the infamous teen.
"I forgive Luke Gatti," chef Bill McKay wrote in a lengthy letter to The Daily Campus published Thursday.
The 19-year-old Gatti was caught on video Oct. 4 making a drunken fool of himself at the school cafeteria, demanding the manager serve him bacon jalapeño macaroni and cheese.
The manager remained composed, but Gatti escalated the confrontation by shoving him. That's when McKay grabbed the mouthy teen from behind and pinned the punk to the ground.
The cafeteria worker explained that everyone has been guilty of committing stupidities, and while "some mistakes are bigger than others," Gatti's screw-up was enhanced by social media.
"Let me ask you a question. How would you like to have your dumbest mistake you've ever made broadcast to the world?” the letter said. “How would you like to be turned into a pariah?"
McKay referenced an apology video Gatti posted on YouTube almost one week after the embarrassing incident.
"I'm going to start by apologizing to all the staff involved in my incident, especially the manager," the seemingly repentant teen said in the video.
